But, the people who suffer for that are not the failing leaders, but the rank-and-file. Lafayette campus laid off several long-time faculty in 2020 and 2021. No job security for anyone who isn't a Systems Office vice-president, no accountability for anyone who is. Financial state of college will continue to be bad, layoffs will continue. review_title: Ivy Tech Community College is losing sight of its main purpose; teaching
pros: Students can receive an adequate education that leads to career opportunities that are only possible with a degree or certificate.
cons: Ivy Tech Community College is pushing a "conveyor-belt" method of extracting tuition from students. The plan is to get students in and out as quickly as possible. This sounds good in theory, but students are losing the "community college" experience where they should have better access to personal assistance. Further, full-time professors are assigned 7-9 classes per semester. It is a madhouse.

review_title: It's alright - I wish teachers were more talkative with each other
pros:
About half the students were attentive and interacted with the material in a genuine way.
Folks are generally nice.
Access to printing facilities.
6am access to school, so I can prepare.
cons:
Teachers are forced to use the McGraw-Hill software, which is naturally constrictive in how content can be presented to students. Whoever decided to use this was not a biology teacher.
In my small class, about half of students plagiarized each other or from an online source. This was after I asked them to PLEASE ask me for help on completing the assignment. "Don't wait until the last minute!" Sound familiar?
Unusual grading percentage criteria that was subject-wide and campus-wide (I think, can't remember) - this was to cater to student complaints!
Unless you're full-time and can be on campus to gossip around and whatnot, you will not be included in decision-making.

job_title: Department Chair in South Bend, IN
pros: The Deans are very loyal and trustworthy. They work within their parameters to help you succeed. Faculty truly want to help students succeed. Overall, it is a great place for students to get an affordable education that does transfer to a lot of schools if they choose to further their 2-year degree.
cons: There is not a whole lot of room for growth and regardless of expertise that is brought to the table, the words "We can't do that." come up a lot.  The institution in the region where I am is in the red a lot and no budget for our department.  I pay a lot out of my own pocket for faculty development and they do not reimburse you for furthering your education claiming that it is not necessary for your job. They expect you to drive 6 hours in one day for professional development that is required without overnight accommodations.  They pile on more and more responsibilities each year and there has only been 1 raise across the board in the last 6 years. I can get an increase of $20K, just going across state lines for the same job.

pros: The wonderful co-workers who care about the students are the best part of working at Ivy Tech.  The retirement benefits are good.
cons: The college is ran like a business - you are expected to keep your office door open all of the time, or, heaven forbid, a closed door means you do not care about Ivy Tech.  They expect you to be "on duty" on evenings as well as weekends and require you to obtain their permission to work other part-time jobs.  You are under their total control once you work for them.  They say their ethics are high, yet the way they treat employees makes you wonder if they know what ethics are.  The place is top-heavy in management and full of office politics.  If you do not say "hello" to certain people in a certain way you will get reprimanded by your supervisor.  The insurance offerings are now full of high-deductible and co-pays.  The finances are shaky, as enrollments continue to decline.  The place is obsessed with data - sometimes if students complain they will tell you to pass the student even if the student has a failing grade.

job_title: Program Chair in Michigan City, IN
pros: Helping students earn their degrees is very fulfilling. The majority of faculty are hard working, dedicated people.
cons: Although not all campuses are toxic, ours is. Lots of lip service, but nothing improves unless you happen to be one of the chancellor's favored few. No support from our administration - just a lot of blame for declining enrollment.

review_title: Change is the only thing constant!
pros: I absolutely love working with the students.  It gives me great pleasure to be their guide on their education journey.  Faculty and staff are great people with big hearts.
cons: "Leadership" is lacking.  Morale of employees is at an all time low.  Crisis management is practiced daily.  Communication is lacking in all areas.  There are too many chiefs and not enough Indians.  Central office has VP for everything making enough to support the salaries of many front line employees like faculty/staff.  Many of these people have never worked Higher Education or "know" someone.  However, there is a budget crisis that is causing faculty/staff to lose their jobs.

review_title: Workstudy work at Learning Center for tutoring
pros:
The supervisor was very good and appreciative of the work that I performed.  There was
a preliminary training session when I began the position and it covered issues and items
relevant to the position.  Ongoing support and advice was given as the job progressed
in service to the students and interaction with the college's tutors.
cons:
There were instances when a student had to wait for a long period for his turn, due
to times the influx of many students, waiting to be served.  This created a situation
where they could not wait any longer and had to leave (attend a class or attend to another
responsibility.)  Everyone was given an equal amount of time in tutoring, but sometimes
the queue of students became to long to deal with in a timely manner.

review_title: Great Work to Life Balance and Benefits
pros: Ivy Tech has an awesome work to life balance. With generous amounts of paid time off, nice  401k contribution and educational opportunities for full time employees. The team I work for and with are great.
cons: Pay is below average unless you are in the top management, raises aren't based on merit for the majority of staff. There doesn't seem to be a lot of room for advancement, the college is going through some restructuring challenges. Change only comes from the "top" down.

job_title: Dr of Philosophy in Cleveland, OH
pros: It's great to see students grow as individuals, develop their own values and politics, and succeed on assignments by acquiring the skills specified in course objectives. It's also nice to apply the pedagogy developed over a long graduate student career and to know one's hard-won academic achievement is extrinsically valuable and practical.
cons: Low pay, no benefits, no job security, long hours grading (depending on subject/course) very little to no recognition with little to no opportunity for full-time employment. This particular school had an issue with the administration asserting itself at will to the point of interrupting instructors' classes and admonishing faculty for voicing concerns about quality assurance programs and rewards which were offered with little to no regard for the integrity of institutional and professional practice.

pros: You get to teach in a subject you love. As an adjunct, you are outside of most of the politics. Compensation is good, but very low if you take into consideration that you will probably be driving to several campuses. Most of the students (especially the returning adults) are working hard to improve their lives and appreciate good teaching.
cons: The pointless activities increase every semester. In addition to teaching and grades, you have to attend seminars, take online training, submit student progress reports, and enter attendance. Driving (especially in winter) cuts into how much you earn per hour. The rules change constantly about how many classes you can teach.

review_title: Students Are Great - Leadership Not So Much
pros: Students attending the college want to better themselves and most staff try their best to assist them.  Front line staff  and middle managers (coordinators/directors) do what they can with the few resources they have.
cons: Creation of "Campus President" positions have turned the campuses against one another.  Good staff are leaving because of poor management at the Vice Chancellor/Campus President level.  What was once a team atmosphere quickly turned into script from Game of Thrones.

review_title: Don't plan on a career with Ivy Tech
job_title: Full-time Faculty Member in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
Strong benefit program (watch out for delayed retirement plan access).

They are really good at spending money on new buildings and remodeling (why did they need Italian marble for the entry way of the NMC building?)
cons:
Low pay, living in Indianapolis, incompetence and nepotism are the rule for department chairs and up.

Management has lost sight of education, they are focused on administration and justifying more positions and pay for useless administrators. The faculty full-time to adjunct ratio is 30-70 and among the lowest in the country. Management bloviates about student completion ratios but seem to be clueless about the importance of faculty vs. administration.

Promotions seem to be dictated by who is playing golf with Tom, or what family you were born into.

pros: Pay is pretty good for part-time job. Free class each semester after one year of employment.
cons: Completely incompetent boss (one over my immediate supervisor) who talks badly about her employees to their peers. Was interviewed and hired without ever speaking to HR, so I found out about benefits (discounts, etc.) little by little over time. Boss seemed to take pleasure in making her employees cry, especially one in particular who was more vulnerable. I've worked 1-on-1 with Fortune 10 executives, doctors, union workers and many other diverse people. Never came across anyone like her. And I'm not the first. From what I understand, others have complained, but nothing was done about it. Fortunately, my immediate supervisor was outstanding. Otherwise, I would have left sooner. Was planning on taking classes at Ivy Tech this year, but can't seem to stomach sending them my money.

review_title: Good place to work, at least as a part-time gig.
pros: The hourly rate they pay is definitely fair, especially if you have an advanced degree. Students are usually nice and don't have entitlement issues you may find at bigger universities.
cons: Students, while nice, tend to have lower retention rates. Especially considering how many have children and home issues, it is likely (and depressing) to see many of your students no longer show up to class. Getting a full-time teaching job here is very difficult, so unless you have other work then the nice hourly pay is negated.

pros: Tuition remission, good use to technology to help you do your jobs.
cons: Low pay, low salary increases when they do happen, high deductible insurance, regional leadership lacking, highly political environment, nepotism, very low morale and it's not clear if regional leadership is clueless to it or it does not care.Too many people get away with saying, "It's not my job".  If people aren't doing their jobs, there are few consequences.  Since raises are not based on performance, those who are poor performing employees benefit the same as those who care and take pride in a job well done.

pros: Working for Ivy Tech is great because there is a balance work-life and the people here treat you as you are all part of a big family. The benefits package is also great. When you work here you belong to a whole family and everyone is there to help each other, whether it be with work or other issues you may need help with.
cons: Sometimes there can be a lack of communication through the college which causes difficulty to do ones job. If there were a more consistant message going across between and an insurance that the message was received properly it would help out a lot. There are too many times that one will interpret a message one way and it mean something totally different to someone else.

review_title: Community is great but pay is low
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Bloomington, IN
pros: The staff, faculty, and students at Ivy Tech Community College are all friendly and worth knowing. I have met a lot of great people. The class sizes are small (7-25 students) and the Bloomington campus has nice classrooms, library, computer labs, a cafe, and a comfortable adjunct office.
cons: The major downside of working as an adjunct with Ivy Tech Community College is the low pay and no benefits. I am only getting paid about $1500 for an online 8-week class this summer and I ordinarily make a little over $6300 for teaching four courses in a 16-week semester. To provide comparison, at the local university an adjunct can make about $6000 per course and adjuncts are only expected/allowed to teach two courses per semester.

review_title: Beware the fake positive posts by administrators
pros: There are a few opportunities to learn new skills.  Many colleagues are genuinely nice people.  Students are amazingly dedicated.
cons: Administrators have no teaching experience.  The leviathan bureaucracy is overwhelming.  Pay is 1/2 to 2/3rds what you can get elsewhere.  The best faculty leave, which is why you are now seeing fake posts by administrators saying that Ivy Tech is great.  No one, I mean NO ONE, that is faculty thinks this is a good job.  Faculty are used, abused, and ridiculed constantly.  If you are thinking about joining Ivy Tech, simply look at the pay in any other state nearby.  At a recent Program Chair Summit, the CEO appeared to be drunk, couldn't work the clicker, and ended his presentation short (20 minutes out of 60 scheduled).

pros: Great retirement contribution. Nice amount of vacation and sick days.
cons: It’s hard to move into better positions. Usually there is someone in mind for that position. They don’t care if you are essentially already doing that particular job. Raises aren’t equal to the cost of living. The pay gap between senior employees and the employees on the front line everyday is huge, the wealth can be spreaded.  I personally know people who work harder and get paid way less than another department. They are also known to pigeon hole part-time employees.

pros: The people I worked directly with were very passionate about helping students and teaching.  Also, I had a lot of flexibility with my hours.
cons: The school, though growing and thriving, does not give full time positions to people that deserve them or have committed to the school, rather passing them up for academics with higher degrees (that they will have to pay more, so the rest of us would make less and have to get by without any benefits).

pros: Nice people to work with.  not management
cons:
They are outsourcing everything .  Pay is low,  no chance to advance . they got rid of good hard working people ,  if your black and work in NW Indiana  , go for it you will advance .  
yes I said it, too much of that going on there..  They don't loom out for the students , its all about signing up kids for classes even if there is no job market out there for them , CEO, Thomas Snyder makes a ton of money,  and is running the place in the ground .

review_title: Students are wonderful but management is out of touch with the students and faculty
pros: Very caring faculty and co-workers.
cons: Management seems to think the place is a business.  Where else are professors on duty 7 days a week?  Where else does a professor have to keep office door open during office hours as well as do community service (policy not enforced in all Ivy Tech regions).  They have you do extra 3 hours for advising but no students to advise.  Constantly changing policies with no communication of the changes.

job_title: Assistant Professor in East Chicago, IN
pros: You make a valuable contribution to the community.  Students are genuinely appreciative of teachers' efforts and are interested in learning.  Excellent benefit package.
cons: Isolation from other faculty; very low pay scale so you have to work other jobs to make ends meet.  Lack of technology in classrooms.

review_title: Really great students, improving facilities but very low pay, no loyalty and little consistency
pros:
I really enjoyed the freedom to teach as I saw fit to great students. 
The Ivy Tech of the past is gone and the facilities improve exponentially every year.
cons:
Hot and Cold management.
Unclear and phony promises for any sort of improvement.
No constancy from one semester to another.
Few long term plans possible with the Company.

review_title: Has a lot of potential to be a great place to work.
job_title: Assistant Professor in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Helping students reach their goals. Great place to work IF you land in the right department.
cons: Too bureaucratic and top down for a college.  Pay is on the lower end of the scale.  Some faculty have jaded viewpoint of the student population.  Not every student is looking to cheat or scheme the system.  Low employee moral, and most people fear the leadership rather than respect it.

pros: The faculty are very talented and committed.   Teaching and working with students is great.  I love to teach and this is the only reason I remain and the only reason the overall satisfaction rating is a 2 instead of 1.
cons: Leadership is poor and the college is very top heavy.   Faculty are generally not respected and there is too much micromanagement from top to bottom (and faculty are seen to be the bottom).   At this point, I am concerned for the future of the college.

review_title: Good school but pay is not the best
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Traditional public community college, good support for adjuncts via Pearson resources, space to work (large adjunct office) w/computer & printer.  Blackboard has good IT support, rooms have decent technology, health benefits available for adjuncts though not underwritten.  Few meetings to attend as adjuncts, classes available in a five-county area.
cons: Currently fewer classes than I'd like so salary is low -- a little more seniority may help.  Six class maximum load means up to 140+ students at the beginning of the semester ... you'd better make grading easy on yourself!

pros: Ivy Tech allowed me to both advise students and teach as an adjunct. I never worked at a main campus, always at satellites, which gave me some great flexibility and really helped me get to know my students. Benefits were also excellent, with a good amount of paid time off.
cons: Promotional opportunities were VERY limited unless you were already at a high level in the administration. I knew many advisors who worked until they got enough experience and then transfered to a university. Turnover was high at the main campus but very low at the satellites.

pros: The health, dental, vacation and other benefits are outstanding.  They treat the professors very well.  Pay was average for Indiana.
cons: Very poor upper management.  They have no sense of direction and for the most part treat all non-faculty personnel as a dime a dozen.  Very difficult to believe anything that comes from IT management as they have lied repeatedly to us over the past few years.  Central office never works with students or faculty yet they don't listen to the people who do.

pros: Since President Snyder came to the college in 2007, many changes have been implemented and streamlined. Some of the changes aren't great, but many of them are very necessary. The college has people that have been around for many years and have completely resisted the changes... but many of those people are leaving or gone now, and it's making room for forward thinkers. The college is run like a business now, which was quite necessary. Finally, a student can take a course at one campus and it is the same course (and transferrable) to another campus across the state. When I began working there, it wasn't the case at all. At that time, the college totally lacked consistency. Again, some of the changes aren't the best- for the most part, I applaud President Snyder for the direction he has taken the college in the last 7 years. Overall, it is now a far more professional place of employment and I would consider returning to the college FT (now that some of the people that needed to go are no longer there, and there is more professional leadership in place.) Local leadership has changed quite a bit in the last 2 years- and definitely for the better.
cons: salaries... some positions are overpaid, while many are underpaid. Historically, there have been a lot of slackers that were allowed to keep their jobs because of who they knew (mostly a local management issue) and there was a great deal of nepotism in hiring (again, at least locally). However, with all of the changes President Snyder has implemented- many of the slackers are going or gone, and new hiring practices for upper management (and all positions really) has eliminated much of the nepotism (also, changing local management has impacted these things as well). Unfortunately, I left before there were changes in local management (which may have made all the difference for me). At that time and due to that dynamic, there was no work-life balance for me; we were prevented from career growth and promotion and "leadership" was terrible. Under new local leadership, I believe those things are changing. You will hear some say differently and complain about the changes over the last several years, including the change in leadership... but those are the people that still need to go, honestly. They want to do things the same way they did 20 years ago... there are some that barely work at all and make 3x the money of their counterparts who do... and they are the folks that have made the environment hostile to work in in the past.

pros: Great benefits.  Great relationship with coworkers on my particular campus.
cons: Communication is terrible from upper management.  I am given assignments twice by different supervisors and they do not communication with one another.  When supervisors don't do their jobs, it makes your job more difficult.  Morale is low on campus and there is a high turn over rate on my particular campus.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great retirement, decent benefits, some nice coworkers, many students who truly want and need to better themselves through education.
cons: Faculty are treated like fast food workers, with absolutely no respect for their education or expertise.  College is being run like a corporation instead of an academic institution.  My chair is incompetent and no one seems to care.  They expect faculty to work when they are off contract/on break.

pros: You will not meet friendlier or more concerned people anywhere.  They are 100% dedicated to serving the students, graduating them and getting them into good lives, and that attitude pervades the institution on all levels.  Central office and upper-level site administration is extraordinarily accessible and responsive.  Many faculty/staff development opportunities.  Excellent tuition benefit (6 credit hours free each semester for employee AND immediate family).
cons: Even for an adjunct job the pay is low.  There are several mandatory meetings each year that occur outside of the contract period, which means a half-day of unpaid work. Despite assertions and public declarations of the importance of the 70% of faculty who are adjunct, the administration rarely asks for adjunct faculty opinions when making major decisions.  Course evaluations by students happen but the instructor is not offered the opportunity to review the results.  The friendliness and concern sometimes borders on cult-like:  there are a lot of overly peppy, Pollyanna-ish people in the administration.  Health benefits for adjuncts are available but are 100% employee-paid and aren't very good for the high cost.  Once flush and expanding, the system is now losing enrollment and money and is cutting back on courses and sites; they are also reducing the per-adjunct maximum course load to avoid being required to pay benefits under the ACA.  Administration is heavy on low-paid clerical workers.

pros: Working with students is great. Ivy Tech has a diverse collection of students from all walks of life.
cons: Upper management has lost touch with student population and faculty. They have way too many executives/vice presidents and keep adding more (at the expense of funding for faculty, programs, and student activities).

pros: The school and many of its staff are great people to work with. Students who are motivated make the job worthwhile. The ability to take classes at the school free of charge for adjuncts was a great benefit.
cons:
Once the ACA came on board, the number of allowable "Contact Hours" were reduced to no more than 9. In some cases, that means only one class per semester.   They do not pay by credit hour, but by contact hour which are listed as more and hence, reduce compensation or the ability to pick up more classes. Because of this, often if an adjunct wants to teach the single class (Such as is available in Math or Science classes where the credit hours are 4 but the contact hours are 5), we have to decide if we want to work full-time somewhere else or 2 part time jobs.   I left because taking a full time job would have interfered with the one class I would have gotten from the college.

Students are often rude and have the feeling of entitlement. I had numerous students who had, quite obviously, been passed in classes that they would fail elsewhere argue that I had to give them an A.  My department head rarely actually backed me up which was not helpful when a student is failing but filing complaints because they felt the work was too hard. Despite my holding office hours and being available without compensation to help them at any time. The students did not come to those times for assistance before complaining. 

Adjuncts are overworked and grossly underpaid. Full time positions are rarely offered to adjuncts, instead they often go to outside applicants. 

If one teaches an online course, the faculty member's hands are basically tied and the students do not understand that we have little to no say in the course content.  The same goes for remedial courses. These are designed by someone at a higher level.  Instructors have no say in what is taught. In essence, we're treated like high school teachers following a state curriculum. 

Many of the management were more business men over educators.

pros: Teach small classes.  Flexibility on times you teach.  Respect for adjunct faculty within the college, since most of the professors are adjunct.
cons: Not the most motivated students.  Little room for advancement.  Not well compensated.  Pay is by the contact hour, so not paid for time preparing and grading outside of class.  No benefits.

review_title: Not quite the absolute low for part-time faculty, but close
pros: No one will observe your teaching, give you negative feedback, or micromanage your classroom activities.  Your pay is usually calculated accurately (though not always), and it arrives on time.  It's easy to get hired as an adjunct.  The buildings are very comfortable and well-appointed.  Parking is free.  You can help people.
cons:
First, the pay is very, very low.  Ivy Tech measures it by hours in the classroom, but of course there is a significant amount of time spent grading and doing mandatory administrative work, so the actual hourly rate can be around minimum wage, depending on how much time it takes for you to grade assignments and how many degrees you have (fewer degrees = lower pay).  I gauge my own pay as ranging between $12.50-$20 hour.  To give you another sense of how low the pay is for adjuncts, if I taught 8 classes per year (full-time at other institutions), I would earn around $16,000. There is an irony here in that Ivy Tech likes to talk about how its goal is to lift people out of poverty.  Also, a high percentage of time spent commuting to class (I can spend more time driving to/from a class than time teaching it) cuts down on the effective net salary you can get.  Don't expect a promotion to full-time faculty status, either.  Ivy Tech keeps the number of full-time faculty to the bare minimum for accreditation.

Second, the administration can be quite peculiar, if not offensive, in communication with its adjunct faculty.  We have had a series of emails about how we should not worry because our president is doing everything he can to prevent having to give us health insurance.  WTF?  I am supposed to be horrified at the idea of being insured?  Apparently.  The pain of hearing this is worse because I know at least two adjuncts who got cancer in the past when they were uninsured.  Currently, Ivy Tech is avoiding giving its adjuncts health insurance by not allowing them to teach more than three classes except when it can't find enough faculty to teach all its courses.  Then (I hear) it gives the adjuncts four classes or more, but it pays the federal fine rather than provide health insurance for them.  As for other benefits for which adjuncts are eligible, there are two free classes per semester after you've taught two semesters, and you're allowed to put your own money into a TIAA-CREF plan (but no employer contribution).  

Third, teaching students is a constant challenge which doesn't get much respect from the administration.  There is a fair amount of racial/ethnic tension, and though students seldom make offensive remarks during class, they do make some appallingly paranoid and hateful remarks before and after class.  The rate of absences and/or lateness is huge -- I regularly start class with two or three students out of a nominal thirty.  Some of the students are smart, ambitious types who are concurrently enrolled in a four-year institution and are just coming to Ivy Tech for a cheap and easy way to get their general ed requirements out of the way.  Some are barely literate and are coming to Ivy Tech for the sole purpose of collecting a Pell Grant.  There are quite a few students who are either learning-disabled or immigrants with limited English, both of which groups have unique needs.  It's difficult to create assignments that challenge everyone without leaving some people utterly incapable of doing the work.  The administration is not in favor of flunking out a large percentage of students, so you either must give easy assignments, or find some other way to pass people whose work really merits an F.  Multiple-choice, open-book exams occur quite often.

Finally, the allocation of money is always a constant source of minor tension.  I teach in a wonderful, beautiful building -- probably the most beautiful building I've ever taught in.  But the college can't find funding to provide markers and an eraser for the whiteboard, and it has suggested that the faculty buy their own (the expensive sort only, at further inflated prices from the campus bookstore).  Students who are so poor they can barely feed and house themselves are charged high prices for textbooks -- the prices are actually marked up above list price at the college bookstore, and students are told to shop there instead of online.  At the same time, the college does not put much effort that I can see in helping students find jobs after graduation.  The number of "success stories" that are promulgated usually involve students who managed to get into a four-year institution after graduating from Ivy Tech, not students who succeeded in finding good jobs.  I get the sense that while the "official" cost of attending Ivy Tech is very low (tuition really is dirt cheap), the college is trying to make up for it by forcing students to buy overpriced textbooks and unnecessary "study aids."

Weirdly, my impression is that Ivy Tech administration is not really interested in education.  There's very little attention paid to what you do as an adjunct. Instead, the focus seems to be on meeting federal requirements to continue getting money, adding new buildings to campus, being visible, and getting the local businesses to donate money or supplies.  I think I've heard more about how important it is for faculty to counsel students and to encourage them to re-enroll than how important it is for faculty to teach them anything.  Emails flow copiously about the hiring of new staff members or staff departures, but there are few emails about new faculty or faculty departures, or anything at all academic-related.  It's really important whether you've contributed to the college's annual charity drive for the United Way, but there's zero discussion about the best textbook for a course.

pros: I enjoyed teaching adults.  It is added bonus that the other adjuncts are very supportive.  Each semester there I had the chance to participate in the professional development sessions that the school offers the adjunct faculty!  Also had the opportunity do complete the Quality Matters training course that is the first qualification of teaching online for Ivy Tech.
cons: If you are looking for steading income, this is not the place.  You have to request to teach courses every semester and you are not guarantee the classes you signed up for.

review_title: Used to Be a great place to work part time..., used to
pros: Great pay and some great folks to work with. If I say anymore, it would be obvious who I am so I am just going to stick with that. There is your 20 word min Glassdoor. Haha.
cons: Control change was ridiculous. So Indy knows what is best for us? I don't think so. It is turning into a place that no one wants to be a part of. That is sad.

pros: Great work life balance, benefits are okay
cons:
compensation is indeed laughable
Individuals are very territorial about their job to the point that they forget the big picture (helping the students)
There is positively NO room for growth
There is NO training for employees
and they refused the hear ideas on how to make the college better!

pros: The students are great, and the FT and PT faculty are dedicated. There is some flexibility in the work schedule, as long as your immediate supervisor likes you. If he/she doesn't, well...
cons: Administration does not listen to those "in the trenches" and any advice or complaint falls on deaf ears. Middle management is too worried about keeping their jobs to support the faculty. We're constantly asked to do more with less. We've even been strong-armed to award grades students didn't earn in order to "retain" students, and improve our completion rates.

pros: There are great retirement benefits, and the staff is always extremely helpful. This is a place that really focuses on student success and engagement.
cons: The college is going through some administrative changes- searching for a new president, and the provost left last semester. The future will see what new initiatives are instilled and what old ones are discontinued.

review_title: Very supportive faculty and staff. Enjoyed teaching.
pros: Faculty really wants the students to succeed.  Students who are at the correct level academically for the class, and recognize the hard work necessary to learn well, appreciate the efforts of the faculty.
cons: As a necessity, employment as an adjunct instructor is enrollment dependent.  So many students are not academically prepared to enter college, and thus do not pass their fall Math and/or English class; this greatly reduces enrollment - and employment -  in the spring semester.

pros: With only ~70 people in the centralized IT organization, employees get to work on numerous projects of high importance to the college at a whole.  With over 830,000 active users, you get to work on systems at a scale rarely seen in the State of Indiana.
cons: Despite the larger number of students, the College lacks the financial resources of the state universities.  Lack of available funds can delay the ability to complete some projects at a given speed.

pros: Amazing co-workers, cozy, helpful environment, clean, flexible hours, fun events
cons: Part-timers are not included in most benefits that full-timers receive and getting a raise as a part-timer is very difficult.

review_title: Faculty are amazing - Administration not so much.
pros: Good benefits, appropriate salary, up-to-date technology, good PTO program, lots of support.
cons: Administration is more concerned about money, to the point of tying the hands of faculty and working them beyond exhaustion. Also, faculty is often the ones put on the chopping block when money becomes tight. Without faculty, who is going to teach?

review_title: It has been a great opportunity and has opened many doors.
job_title: Student Worker-Center for Academic Excellence in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Helping the students is rewarding, a lot of freedom to do help students you see best, the supervisors are easy to work with, easy to work around life situations, you get free classes every semester to take.
cons: As a student worker no real opportunity to get a an actual part time employment, you get shuffled into different departments that you know nothing about, and no way to get a raise in pay.

pros: Great flexibility in schedule, everyone looks out for each other, a great learning experience, positive reinforcement, great way to make many connections if you just start taking classes at Ivy and you get first-hand knowledge of career hunting.
cons: The schedule is limited on your financial aid status(Unsubsidized and subsidized  loans taken per year can impact the work hours you are allowed).

review_title: I have enjoyed working at Ivy Tech Community College. It has a disciplined and well-organized work atmosphere and ethic.
job_title: Teacher/Instructor of Mathematics in Indianapolis, IN
pros: It is like serving the public and those who need support.
cons: As a community college, there are some issues of student attendance and that needs special attention.

review_title: The experience helped me to grow while assisting students and it prepared me for the advantages and disadvantages.
job_title: Student Service Technician in Indianapolis, IN
pros: There are great benefits working for this company and after somany years they do recognize employees for their contributed service.
cons: The downsides for me was working 5 days a week at 40 hours, when working 10 hours a day for 4 days would have sufficed.

pros: You get to work with a lot of great people who genuinely care about the success of Ivy Tech students. It truly is a compassionate bunch. It's great to see employees care so deeply about the Ivy Tech mission.
cons: Very limited to no room for growth. It seems as if a lot of people stay where they're put. There isn't very much emphasis on helping employees further their career within Ivy Tech.

review_title: ITCC review of company from assistant professor
pros: If you are lucky to have an awesome program chair, the support is incredible!
cons: Inundated with administrative tasks, which detracts from faculty duties, ultimately effects the students negatively

review_title: Very low pay, no pay during semester breaks.
job_title: Mathematics Tutor in Terre Haute, IN
pros: Librarian is great and they are are extremely flexible with hours. You basically can set up your own hours each semester and can also add hours as well.
cons: The problems with working here is that you get reduced hours during breaks between semesters, therefore you don't receive hardly any hours if any at all.

pros: Travel is such a pleasure and a chance to get to know cultures languages opportunity to get to know your best and to interact with different people to get out od ur confort zone and live life supreme.
cons: When you spend much time traveling sometimes is difficult to see family and close friends but is worth it.

pros: Like most jobs there are good thing and bad things.  Right before and at the beginning of a semester, it is extremely busy.  Even when it is the busiest, most of the staff and faculty are helpful and friendly,
cons: The College is restructuring which is causing stress for the faculty and the staff.

pros: Great place. many of the other employees have been at the college for many many years. My neighbors in cubes been there 17 and 22 years.
cons: haven't really experienced any down sides. been there 2+ years and still enjoying my work, which alone may be why I enjoy the university

review_title: A "Good Ol' Boys" Club with Very Little Room to Grow
pros: There are some very nice people who work there and the college is helping students graduate who wouldn't otherwise have an opportunity to go to college.
cons: Politics rule everything and if you aren't "drinking the Kool-Aid" you won't be promoted, supported, or otherwise have a pleasant experience.

review_title: My experience has been enjoyable and casual.
pros: Ivy Tech does not manage your teaching excessively.  I was given the freedom to choose how to run my class, what content to focus on and what content to leave out.
cons: At times the processes set up to turn in required paperwork can be confusing.  There is excessive email that is sent out to entire groups that clog up your inbox as well.

pros: hourly rates for adjunct instructors were decent. flexibility to teach when and at which locations was a big plus
cons: while the hourly pay is not bad, the amount of work needed to be done outside fo the classroom was more than i cared for

pros:
Laid back atmosphere
Excellent Co-workers
Health and retirement benefits are outstanding
Job is rewarding when you see graduates succeed
cons:
Low pay in comparison to other institutions
As with all higher ed institutions, enrollment highly dictates advancement and raises
Extremely political

review_title: Unfulfilled Dreams of Working for a Community College
pros: Ivy Tech is a two year college and you can help students who might not otherwise consider education.
cons: The local management is very egocentric focusing on them rather than the students.  The local leadership completely micromanages staff.

review_title: Little respect, low pay for part-time employees
pros: Nice, dedicated people. Decent facilities, free parking, and many international students who are passionate about the opportunity. Convenient central location.

pros: Awesome benefits. You're not going to beat what little you're paying in health insurance. Truly excellent retirement package. Also, the percent increase each year (not guaranteed, but usually happens as long as you meet certain criteria) is fantastic.
